title: WUMP
text:
WUMP (730 <a href="AM%20broadcasting">AM</a>, "SportsRadio 730 The UMP") is a <a href="sports%20radio">sports talk</a>-formatted <a href="radio%20station">radio station</a> licensed to <a href="Madison%2C%20Alabama">Madison, Alabama</a>, where its transmitter tower is located. WUMP primarily serves the <a href="Huntsville%2C%20Alabama">Huntsville, Alabama</a>, market, though its studios are located in <a href="Athens%2C%20Alabama">Athens</a>. The station is owned by <a href="Cumulus%20Media">Cumulus Media</a>, based in <a href="Atlanta%2C%20Georgia">Atlanta, Georgia</a>.
Programming.
Sports.
The UMP currently is the home of The "<a href="WJOX-FM">JOX</a> Roundtable" airing from 6 to 10 a.m. Following that is "3 Man Front" from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. The afternoon drive is anchored by "Lockdown Coverage with Arky Shea and Jason Marks" from 2 to 6 p.m. Weekend programming includes "The Bullpen with Tony Mac and Tricky Ricky Fernandez" on Saturdays from 9 to 11 a.m. Evening programming includes <a href="CBS%20Sports%20Radio">CBS Sports Radio</a> when not preempted by live sporting events.
The UMP has an affiliation with the <a href="Westwood%20One%20%28current%29">Westwood One</a> network. As such, the UMP airs all prime-time <a href="National%20Football%20League">NFL</a> games including "<a href="Sunday%20Night%20Football%20%28radio%20program%29">Sunday Night Football</a>," "<a href="Monday%20Night%20Football">Monday Night Football</a>," "<a href="Thursday%20Night%20Football">Thursday Night Football</a>" and the specialty prime-time games on Thanksgiving, Christmas, as well as Saturday games during December. These are in addition to the Sunday-afternoon doubleheader.
The UMP is an affiliate of the <a href="Alabama%20Crimson%20Tide">Alabama Crimson Tide</a> network, carrying every <a href="Alabama%20Crimson%20Tide%20football">football</a> and <a href="Alabama%20Crimson%20Tide%20basketball">basketball</a> game, the <a href="Alabama%20Crimson%20Tide%20baseball">baseball</a> slate against <a href="Southeastern%20Conference">SEC</a> teams and in the postseason, and a selection of <a href="Alabama%20Crimson%20Tide%20women%27s%20basketball">women's basketball</a> games.
In 2018, The UMP became an affiliate of the <a href="Tennessee%20Titans">Tennessee Titans</a> of the NFL and of the <a href="Nashville%20Predators">Nashville Predators</a> of the NHL.
Part of the UMP's affiliation with Westwood One allows the UMP to carry a large package of <a href="NCAA">NCAA</a> basketball games, the <a href="March%20Madness">March Madness</a> tournament, the <a href="NCAA%20Division%20I%20Men%27s%20Ice%20Hockey%20Tournament">NCAA Division I Men's Ice Hockey Tournament</a>, the <a href="College%20World%20Series">College World Series</a>, the <a href="Women%27s%20College%20World%20Series">Women's College World Series</a> and select <a href="National%20Hockey%20League">NHL</a> games, including the <a href="Winter%20Classic">Winter Classic</a> and the NHL Playoffs concluding with the <a href="Stanley%20Cup">Stanley Cup</a>.
During the spring through the early fall, the UMP is the Huntsville-area station for <a href="Atlanta%20Braves">Atlanta Braves</a> baseball.
Network affiliation.
The station is currently an affiliate of <a href="CBS%20Sports%20Radio">CBS Sports Radio</a>. The station was an <a href="ESPN%20Radio">ESPN Radio</a> affiliate in the late 1990s and early 2000s before losing it to then-rival <a href="WTKI">WTKI</a> (1450 AM) in late 2002. The affiliation returned to WUMP on February 6, 2007, after WTKI was sold and changed formats.
History.
Launch at 1360 AM.
This station received its original <a href="construction%20permit">construction permit</a> for a 500-<a href="watt">watt</a> station broadcasting on 1360 <a href="kHz">kHz</a> from the <a href="Federal%20Communications%20Commission">Federal Communications Commission</a> on September 13, <a href="1982%20in%20radio">1982</a>. The new station was assigned the call letters WABT by the FCC. WABT received its <a href="broadcast%20license">license to cover</a> from the FCC on June 19, 1983. The station aired a <a href="country%20music">country music</a> format to start with.
In June 1985, The Great American Broadcasting Corporation reached an agreement to sell WABT to Excelsior Broadcasting Corporation. The deal was approved by the FCC on July 19, 1985, and the transaction was consummated on January 22, 1986.
Move to 730 AM.
The station had applied to the FCC in September 1983 to change frequencies from 1360 kHz to 730 kHz and increase power to 1,000 watts. In July 1985, after WJMW moved from 730 kHz to 770 kHz, the FCC issued a construction permit for the changes. The new owners had the FCC change the station's callsign to WDKT on December 26, 1985.
With new ownership, new call letters, a new frequency, and increased power in place, the station changed to an <a href="urban%20contemporary">urban contemporary</a> format branded as "D-73".
Financial problems.
Facing increasing financial difficulties, in February 1989 the license for this station was involuntarily transferred from Excelsior Broadcasting Corporation to Excelsior Broadcasting Corporation, Debtor-In-Possession. The involuntary transfer was approved by the FCC on March 2, 1989. In April 1989, Vascular Diagnostic Labs bought out the previous shareholders of Excelsior Broadcasting Corporation, the licensee for this station. The transfer of control was approved by the FCC on July 13, 1989.
In August 1989, with the financial issues resolved and the previous shareholders bought out, Excelsior Broadcasting Corporation was dissolved and the license was involuntarily transferred to Vascular Diagnostic Labs owner Dr. Merlin Kelsick. The transfer was approved by the FCC on November 29, 1990.
News and talk.
The call letters were changed to WBBI on August 19, 1991, after Dr. Merlin Kelsick completed a deal to sell the station to Phoenix Capital Corporation. The deal was approved by the FCC on September 12, 1991, and the transaction was consummated on September 17, 1991. The station then switched to a <a href="news%20radio">news</a>/<a href="talk%20radio">talk</a> format.
The station's callsign was changed to WKMW on June 1, 1993. In June 1993, Phoenix Capital Corporation reached an agreement to sell WKMW to Madison Radio Company, Inc. The deal was approved by the FCC on July 19, 1993, and the transaction was consummated on October 28, 1993.
Sports radio.
In May 1995, Madison Radio Company, Inc., reached an agreement to sell the station to Tennessee Valley Radio, Inc. The deal was approved by the FCC on July 31, 1995, and the transaction was consummated on October 3, 1995. The new owners had the FCC change the station's call letters to the current WUMP on October 6, 1995. The new call sign was chosen to match the station's new <a href="sports%20radio">sports radio</a> format and branding as "The Ump", an abbreviation of <a href="wikt%3Aumpire">umpire</a>.
Corporate ownership.
The Dunnavant family of Athens owned the station from the early 1990s until agreeing to sell it to Cumulus Broadcasting in 2003. This ended a 55-year presence in the area by Athens Broadcasting, founded in 1948 by Homer Felix "Pap" Dunnavant.
On April 1, 2003, WUMP was sold by Athens Broadcasting Co. (William E. Dunnavant, president) to Cumulus Broadcasting Inc. as part of a four-station deal with a total sale price of $22 million in cash and Cumulus common stock. The acquisition of the stations was completed in July 2003. WUMP remains co-owned with former Dunnavant stations <a href="WVNN%20%28AM%29">WVNN</a> and <a href="WZYP">WZYP</a>, in addition to <a href="WHRP">WHRP</a> and <a href="WWFF-FM">WWFF-FM</a>.
Translators.
WUMP's programming is also carried on a <a href="broadcast%20translator">broadcast translator</a> station to extend or improve the coverage area of the station. WUMP programming first appeared on the FM signal on November 26, 2008.
